title: How to Use a Toilet Seat Cover

steps.title: Pull the toilet seat cover straight out of the container.
steps.content: Pull the toilet seat cover straight out of the container. Enter the stall, and look for the plastic container housing the toilet seat covers. Grip the outside of one, and pull it up gently to separate it from the rest. [1] X Research source The cover should come out easily with little effort.

steps.title: Pinch the 3 inside joints to release the middle flap section.
steps.content: Pinch the 3 inside joints to release the middle flap section. Along the “bowl” of the cover are 3 small attachments of paper securing the flap to the outer ring. Before you set the cover down, gently rip off these joints with your fingers so the flap can fall inside the bowl. There is 1 joint on the left side, 1 in the middle, and 1 on the right side. [2] X Research source You can simply pinch the paper and the joints should easily rip off. As you do this, avoid ripping off the entire flap.

steps.title: Place the seat cover onto the toilet so the flap goes inside the bowl.
steps.content: Place the seat cover onto the toilet so the flap goes inside the bowl. The flap of the toilet seat cover is the middle, circular section. Align the flap so it falls inside the bowl and the outer ring covers the seat of the toilet completely. The part of the cover where the flap is still connected should meet the front edge of the toilet, opposite the flushing mechanism. [3] X Research source If you put the toilet seat on backward, that’s okay! It really doesn’t matter, as long as the toilet seat is covered.

steps.title: Flush the toilet when finished to automatically dispose of the seat cover.
steps.content: Flush the toilet when finished to automatically dispose of the seat cover. When you finish using the bathroom, you don’t have to take off the cover and dispose of it. The covers are made from a material that breaks down in the water. Simply flush it when you finish. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Inspect the toilet to determine its overall condition.
steps.content: Inspect the toilet to determine its overall condition. When you enter the public bathroom , select a stall with a clean seat and bowl, if you can. If the toilet is spot-free and white, you can use it without adding the cover. Toilet seats are not a threat for germs or disease unless they are very dirty or in rough condition. [5] X Research source When you are in a bathroom with multiple stalls, feel free to look at a few and go with the cleanest one. You can base your decision on overall cleanliness and personal opinion.

steps.title: Cover the toilet seat if there is visible urine or debris.
steps.content: Cover the toilet seat if there is visible urine or debris. If the toilet seat is dirty, it’s a good idea to use a cover. Do this if you see any drops of liquid, dirt, or debris on the seat or around the toilet bowl. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Opt for the toilet seat cover if you have any cuts or open wounds.
steps.content: Opt for the toilet seat cover if you have any cuts or open wounds. If you have a scratch or blemish on your bottom, it’s a good idea to use a toilet seat cover, as germs are more likely to spread through open wounds. [7] X Research source In these cases, toilet seat covers work well as another layer of defense against bacteria.

steps.title: Understand that other household items often have more germs.
steps.content: Understand that other household items often have more germs. Items like sponges, cutting boards, and kitchen counters often have more germs than a toilet seat. In general, toilet seats are rather clean comparatively. Keep this in mind when deciding whether or not to use a toilet seat cover. [8] X Research source Disposable toilet seat covers can be wasteful and harmful for the environment, so try to limit how often you use them.
